disease: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm — see Aortic Aneurysm
symptom3: Deep, constant pain in your abdomen or on the side of your abdomen
symptom6: Gastrointestinal disease including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting
prevention1: Don't use tobacco products. Quit smoking or chewing tobacco and avoid secondhand smoke.
prevention2: Eat a healthy diet. Focus on eating a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, poultry, fish and low-fat dairy products. Avoid saturated fat, trans fats and limit salt.
prevention3: Wear a mask when physical distancing is not possible.
prevention4: Keep your blood pressure and cholesterol under control. If your doctor has prescribed medications, take them as instructed.
prevention5: Cover your nose and mouth with your bent elbow or a tissue when you cough or sneeze.
cause: Tobacco use. Smoking is the strongest risk factor. It can weaken the aortic walls, increasing the risk not only of developing an aortic aneurysm, but of rupture. The longer and more you smoke or chew tobacco, the greater the chances of developing an aortic aneurysm.

prevention1: Wear a mask
prevention2: Clean your hands
diet: While no foods or dietary supplements can prevent or cure COVID-19 infection, healthy diets are important for supporting immune systems
cause: Infection with the new coronavirus (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2) causes coronavirus disease 2019 ( COVID-19 ). The virus that causes COVID-19 spreads easily among people, and more continues to be discovered over time about how it spreads

symptom2: A cough that lasts more than three weeks.
symptom3: Loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss.
prevention1: cover your mouth with a tissue when you cough or sneeze
prevention2: Wash your hands after coughing or sneezing

prevention1: Avoid smoking and drinking.
prevention2: Take healthy diet including fresh fruits, greens and dry fruits.
prevention3: Be happy, and avoid stress and anxiety, as they could impair memory.

symptom1: Pain in lower right side of abdomen (may be followed by vomiting)
prevention1: High fibre enriched food should be included in your daily diet.
prevention2: Maintaining proper and well-balanced can reduce the risk of Appendicitis.
cause: Appendicitis may be caused by various infections such as virus, bacteria, or parasites, in your digestive tract. Or it may happen when the tube that joins your large intestine and appendix is blocked or trapped by stool. Sometimes tumors can cause appendicitis.
diet: Fresh fruit and vegetable juice,Steamed vegetables,Whole grains,Sprouted seeds,Homemade cheese, milk,Fiber rich food

prevention1: Control your blood sugar.
prevention2: Exercise.

symptom2: Lump or area of thickening that can be felt under the skin.
symptom3: Weight changes, including unintended loss or gain.
prevention1: Don't use tobacco. Using any type of tobacco puts you on a collision course with cancer.
prevention2: Eat a healthy diet.
prevention3: Maintain a healthy weight and be physically active

prevention1: Don't smoke.
prevention2: Use disposable items if a family member is infected.

prevention1: Cut Sugar and Refined Carbs From Your Diet
prevention2: Work Out Regularly.
prevention3: Drink Water as Your Primary Beverage.
prevention4: Lose Weight If You're Overweight or Obese

symptom3: Uncontrollable jerking movements of the arms and legs.
prevention1: Get plenty of sleep each night — set a regular sleep schedule, and stick to it.
prevention2: Learn stress management and relaxation techniques.

prevention1: Control chronic health conditions.
prevention2: Protect your eyes from the sun.

prevention1: Eat a Healthy Diet.
prevention2: Keep Yourself at a Healthy Weight.

prevention1: Keep your bedtime and wake time consistent from day to day, including weekends.
prevention2: Stay active — regular activity helps promote a good night's sleep.
prevention3: Check your medications to see if they may contribute to insomnia

prevention1: Avoid hepatitis infection.
prevention2: Stay within recommended alcohol limits.

prevention1: drink water, but drinks like tea and coffee also count.
prevention2: add fresh lemon juice to your water
prevention4: do not eat too much salt.

prevention1: Cannot be prevented but - avoiding tobacco and exposure to pesticides and industrial chemicals might help

symptom5: Swelling in your legs, feet or ankles
prevention1: Don't abuse alcohol. If you do drink alcohol, limit how much you drink and how often.
prevention2: Eat a well-balanced, low-fat diet, such as the Mediterranean diet.
prevention3: Don't eat raw seafood, especially oysters and clams.

prevention1: Eat more salt.
prevention2: Avoid alcoholic beverages.

symptom1: a high temperature of 38C or above.
prevention1: Wear full sleeve protective clothing.
prevention2: Spray insect repellants on your exposed skin.
prevention3: Use a mosquito net over the bed if your bedroom isn't air-conditioned or screened.
diet: Eating soups, stews or drinking fruit juices or dal water, coconut water, etc. are important. Vitamin C and A rich foods such as papaya, beetroots and other citrus foods, etc. with vitamin B complex are important for a malaria patient
cause: Malaria is caused by a single-celled parasite of the genus plasmodium. The parasite is transmitted to humans most commonly through mosquito bites.

symptom1: severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head.
prevention1: Avoid loud noises and bright lights.
prevention2: Pay attention to food choices.
diet: orange, yellow, and green vegetables, such as summer squash, sweet potatoes, carrots, and spinach.carbonated, spring, or tap water.rice, especially brown rice.dried or cooked fruits, particularly non-citrus kinds such as cherries and cranberries.
cause: Changes in the brainstem and its interactions with the trigeminal nerve, a major pain pathway, might be involved. So might imbalances in brain chemicals — including serotonin, which helps regulate pain in your nervous system.

symptom1: Red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales.
symptom2: Small scaling spots (commonly seen in children)
symptom3: Dry, cracked skin that may bleed or itch.
prevention1: Use Moisturizing Lotions.
prevention2: Take Care of Your Skin and Scalp.
cause: Psoriasis is caused, at least in part, by the immune system mistakenly attacking healthy skin cells. If you're sick or battling an infection, your immune system will go into overdrive to fight the infection. This might start another psoriasis flare-up. Strep throat is a common trigger.
diet: A healthy diet lots of fruits and veggies, lean protein, and whole grains -- is a good idea for just about everyone. But some people who have psoriasis say their eating habits can affect their skin.There's no scientific proof that staying away from certain foods or following a specific diet will help your condition. But what you eat and drink may make a difference
